introduction.text: The Biomedical Research Hub (BRH) is a standard-based data ecosystem for securely managing, analyzing and sharing biomedical data to support research communities and collaborations.

buttons.name: Analyze Data
buttons.body: Analyze your selected cases using Jupyter Notebooks in our secure cloud environment
buttons.label: Run analysis

items.name: Discovery
items.tooltip: Use free-text search and tags to rapidly find relevant studies, discover new datasets across multiple resources, and easily export selected data files to the analysis workspace.

items.name: Workspace
items.tooltip: Gen3 workspaces are secure data analysis environments in the cloud that can access data from one or more data resources.

items.name: Example Analysis
items.tooltip: Learn how to use Jupyter Notebooks to explore and visualize data discovered in the Biomedical Research Hub by running a static tutorial notebook, or use one of these examples as a launching point for your own custom analysis.

login.title: Biomedical Research Hub
login.subTitle: Discover, Analyze, and Share Data
login.text: The Biomedical Research Hub (BRH) is a standard-based data ecosystem for securely managing, analyzing and sharing biomedical data to support research communities and collaborations.
login.contact: If you have any questions about access or the registration process, please contact

footerLogos.alt: Center for Translational Data Science at the University of Chicago

authorization.columnTooltip: Filter by data access. Accessible indicates you are authorized to access. Not accessible indicates you are not authorized to access.

match.short_name: Methodology and Advanced Analytics Resource Center

resourceBrowser.title: Jupyter Notebook Tutorials
resourceBrowser.description: The Jupyter notebooks contained in this notebook viewer pull data from various sources to generate and output useful tables, charts, graphs, and models. Each notebook is static, meaning the data being used by the notebooks is not updated in real time. Executable versions of these notebooks are also available in the 'Tutorials' Gen3 Workspace Image.

resources.title: How to access data in Biomedical Research Hub
resources.description: In this Jupyter notebook, we will demonstrate to a new user the different ways of accessing data in the Biomedical Research Hub workspace using the Gen3 SDK and GraphQL

resources.title: JCOIN MOUD Accessibility Analysis
resources.description: In this Jupyter notebook, we used the data from the OEPS database to analyze the Medication for Opioid Use Disorder (MOUD) providers accessibility at state and county level across the United States.

resources.title: Changes In Opioid Treatment Policy During COVID-19
resources.description: In this notebook we used data from NIDA-PDAPS and CDC WONDER mortality data to visualize the relationship between statewide changes in opioid treatment policy and opioid overdose mortality rates in 2020.

resources.title: Gene Expression Analysis of Project TCGA-CHOL
resources.description: In this notebook, we demonstrated how to retrieve RNA expression data of project TCGA-CHOL from Genomic Data Commons (GDC) data portal, and perform data analysis and visualization using a pipeline provided by an R package GDCRNATools.

resources.title: Proteome Data Commons (PDC) Clustergram
resources.description: This notebook attempts to demonstrate the use the PDC API to retrieve the associated clinical metadata for all samples, format the data for analysis using pandas and cluster and visualize the data using the Seaborn clustermap package.

resources.title: MIDRC CT Scan
resources.description: In this notebook we demonstrate how to pull in MIDRC CT scan data, how to view the CT scan images, how to convert the image file format, and how to extract clinical data and file metadata from the DICOM file headers.

resources.title: Data Exploration using Python of Framingham Heart Study Teaching Dataset
resources.description: In this Python tutorial, we demonstrate how to pull the Framingham teaching dataset from BioData Catalyst data commons into a BRH workspace, and perform data exploration and visualization using Python packages.

resources.title: Data Exploration using R of Framingham Heart Study Teaching Dataset
resources.description: In this tutorial, using R code, we will demonstrate how to pull the object file of the Framingham teaching dataset from the BioData Catalyst data commons into a BRH workspace and perform data exploration and visualization using R packages.

resources.title: Data Exploration of CAMP Study Teaching Dataset
resources.description: In this tutorial, we demonstrate how to pull the object file of CAMP study from BioData Catalyst data commons into a BRH workspace, and perform data exploration and visualization using Python packages.

resources.title: Canine Data Commons FASTQ Reader
resources.description: In this tutorial notebook, we demonstrate how to use Gen3 SDK and API to explore and retrieve data from Canine Data Commons. This tutorial also includes a simple example to explore sequence information from a FASTQ file.

resources.title: Unsupervised Data Exploration on Cancer Cell Line Encyclopedia (CCLE)
resources.description: Principal component analysis (PCA) and t-distributed stochastic neighbor embedding (t-SNE) has become valuable tools for unsupervised data exploration. This notebook explores the application of unsupervised learning on Cancer Cell Line Encyclopedia (CCLE) gene expression profiles.

resources.title: PCA of 1000 Genome Phase3 Genotype data
resources.description: Principal components analysis (PCA) is a widely used method in the field of population genetics, providing a model-free method for exploring patterns of relatedness within a collection of individuals. In this notebook, we use the 1000 Genomes Project phase3 release of variant calls data to apply both conventional PCA analysis of the LD-pruned genotype data.

resources.title: MIDRC Open-R1 Clinical Data Analysis
resources.description: In this notebook we will visualize the distribution of subjects accross a variety demographics and their COVID-19 status in the Open-R1 dataset from The Medical Imaging and Data Resource Center.

resources.title: JCOIN Tracking Opioid Stigma
resources.description: In this Jupyter notebook, we used the JCOIN-MAARC (Justice Community Opioid Innovation Network - Methodology and Advanced Analytics Resource Center) Survey Core Survey Project 1/4 to track stigma related to Opioid Use Disorder (OUD) and public attitudes towards persons with OUD as well as how treatment of/for persons with OUD may impact the effect of OUD interventions.

resources.title: OADC CCLE RNA-Seq Visualization
resources.description: This notebook demonstrates how to visualize the gene expression for cell lines of interest. The CCLE gene expression data was pulled from BRH and formatted using Pandas and then visualized using Seaborn.

resources.title: Cox Model Implementation using ACTT Data from NIAID Clinical Trials Data Commons
resources.description: In this notebook, we explore the clinical data from Adaptive COVID-19 Treatment Trial (ACTT) to evaluate the clinical efficacy of remdesivir relative to the control arm in patients hospitalized with COVID-19 as assessed by the time to recovery.

resources.title: Identify Prostate Cancer Biomarker using Machine Learning
resources.description: This notebook demonstrates the analysis of The Cancer Genome Atlas Prostate Adenocarcinoma (TCGA-PRAD) gene expression dataset to understand the steps in a differential expression analysis workflow in the context of DESeq2.

resources.title: Identification of Potential Drug Targets of Inflammatory Bowel Disease
resources.description: This notebook demonstrates an approach to query data in EpiGraphDB to prioritize potential alternative drug targets in the same protein-protein interaction network for Inflammatory Bowel Disease

workspaceRegistrationConfig.workspaceInfoMessage: The BRH workspace provides a standardized computational environment for accessing and analyzing data from multiple data commons. Please fill out this form to request access to the workspace and start computing!
